poem:
Title: "Upon the Threshold, New Roots"

In chambers of power, the ink spatters,
Duty-stamps lift like gulls from hard-beaten shores,
Chase dreams beyond the grey of £300,000 moors. 
Sunak, in his vast manor, clatters.
First homes born from promises, half-lit by Tory moon,
will they flourish or fall to next March's tune? 
Let £425,000 be more than numbers - make it bloom.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sunak pledges to keep stamp duty threshold at £425k for first-time buyers The Conservatives would permanently scrap stamp duty on homes up to £425,000 for first-time buyers, Rishi Sunak is expected to pledge in the party’s election manifesto, in a move that would affect 200,000 households annually. The threshold was raised from £300,000 to £425,000 in the September 2022 mini-budget as a temporary relief measure that is due to expire next March. Related: ‘It makes". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
